reviews.review_text: So far, the character seem naive, sweet, conniving, as well as very human.
These two books are wonderful.  The movies are two of my all-time favorites.

A plot line that is Greek tragedy, yet it is told with such humor, warmth, sweetness, compassion for even its villains. Pagnol transports you to another world and time. His simple, direct, and yet utterly unexpected descriptions of the physical world that is Provence makes you feel that you are right there, in the mistral, the storms of summer. It is a joy to read. I took this two-novel combo paperback with me on a 1-week mountain summer vacation, and I read it every chance I had at least 10 or 15 minutes. Hours by the pool,  10-15 minutes at a time while in line for something, waiting for someone, anything. JdF leads right into the Manon book; they're almost one novel, just in two volumes. I gave my copy away to a friend after I finished because I want someone else to experience the magic of these Pagnol novels. That's why I'm writing this review, and I hope you'll pick this book up, too, and see for yourself.

I made the mistake of loaning it to someone who never returned it so I bought it again. I am intrigued with Pagnol's brilliant and very readable depiction of good and evil-- of every day good people who suffer needlessly because of every day people whose selfishness is really the worst possible evil.
A most enjoyable old fashioned historical novel, great insight into another culture, consumed me into the saga, very hard to put down. Would read it again, highly recommended.
A French classic, can't go wrong with Montand , Auteuil ,Depardieu .Great author, the perfect actors ,I love it

I've already re-read these novels. The story only gets better. I recommend these two works to everyone I know. "Jean de Florette" and "Manon of the Springs" are incredible! My only wish is that there existed a better translation. In some parts, the sentences don't flow right. However, I've never read the orignal works in French. Highly recommended!
I liked the books very much. I hoped the hero would find the spring. I liked Manons revenge. Surprising end.

summary:
In Jean de Florette and Manon of the Springs, Marcel Pagnol (called by Andre Malraux "one of the great writers of our generation" and by Jean Renoir "the leading film artist of his age") achieve the fullest and most satisfying expression of a story that haunted him for years, a Provencal legend of vengeance exacted by a mysterious sheperdess. Pagnol brings to his treatment of this powerful, moving story his dramatist's sense of place, ambience, and character and his keen understanding of the Provencal countryside and its people. 

Rich with twists and ramifications, Jean de Florette and Manon of the Springs sets an idealistic city man against two secretive and deceitful Provencal country men in a superbly realized story of a struggle for life, of crime and punishment, of betrayal and revenge, and of judgment and forgiveness. In this edition, illustrated with images from the acclaimed film adaptation by Claude Berri, North Point presents Pagnol's enduring story in W.E. van Heyningen's exact and sensitive translation.

Biblical in its cadences, epic in its sweep to destiny, and old fashioned in development of character and plot, this saga charts the destruction of a Provencal family.
